messageBody:
Thomas,

I don't think this coverage is off-topic at all, since the coverage testers
I've tried all use JUnit tests to initiate execution of the code.

As it happens, Erich and I measured the coverage of our tests in JUnit 4
today. We used Coverlipse first. I liked the user interface (you initiate
coverage measurement with a new kind of launch configuration), but the
results weren't accurate. We set breakpoints on lines that the tool claimed
weren't covered and execution stopped there. We also tried Clover, which has
a slightly less natural interface (you set an "enable Clover" flag on the
project properties). The results, however, seemed much more accurate.

The result of our testing was that we found two methods out of JUnit 4 that
we felt needed tests. Our overall coverage is 68%, and it seems like it
would be easy to get it up to 80%. However, the only functional code that
really needed more tests were those two methods.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Thomas L Roche
> Sent: Thursday, September 01, 2005 5:28 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] [OT] coverage plugins for eclipse?
>
> Apologies if this is OT, but IMHO coverage measurement (for guiding
> one's test writing) and IDEs (for writing and running one's tests) are
> both at least tangentially related to JUnit ... and I don't know of a
> good list for coverage measurement :-(
>
> I'm wondering, what are folks who use Eclipse (or Eclipse-based
> products) using to do coverage measurement and reporting? One option
> is to just run the coverage tool from the command line or ant, but I'd
> really like something more integrated, e.g.
>
> 0 a run config that would Run>{JUnit, JUnit Plug-in Test} under the
> coverage tool and display results in a view
>
> 1 mark un/covered sources in Outline view or editors
>
> The coverage plugins of which I'm aware are
>
> * Clover
>
> * jcoverage
>
> * Rational Developer (Unfortunately its coverage tools are part of its
> performance-testing tools, which complicates installation and use
> for "normal" testing.)
>
> Are there others?
